attributes.title: Religiosity, calling and basic psychological needs satisfaction among civil servants in Russian subnational government

q1.value: Religiosity, calling and basic psychological needs satisfaction among civil servants in Russian subnational government

q2.value: Aleksandr Kalgin | Andrei Yakovlev | Maria K. Milosh

q5.value: The article was prepared within the framework of the Academic Fund Program at the National Research University Higher School of Economics (HSE) in 2018 - 2019 (grant №18-01-0015) and by the Russian Academic Excellence Project <<5-100>>., I would like to thank Jordan Gans-Morse, Andrei Yakovlev and Andrei Klimenko for their help in collecting the data. I also thank Jesse Campbell, the editor of HSE Working paper series on Public and Social Policy for his helpful comments on early drafts of this paper

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q16.value: 1. H1. religious civil servants are more likely to perceive their work as a calling (more than non-religious civil servants); 2. H2. perceiving one's job as a calling is associated with higher job satisfaction (H2a), lower turnover intention (H2b) and higher subjective well-being (H2c); 3. H3. perceiving one's job as a calling is linked to basic psychological needs satisfaction; 4. H4. Basic psychological needs satisfaction mediates the relationship between calling and work-related outcomes (job satisfaction (H4a) / turnover intention (H4b) / subjective well-being (H4c)).

registration_responses.q1: Religiosity, calling and basic psychological needs satisfaction among civil servants in Russian subnational government
registration_responses.q2: Aleksandr Kalgin | Andrei Yakovlev | Maria K. Milosh
registration_responses.q5: The article was prepared within the framework of the Academic Fund Program at the National Research University Higher School of Economics (HSE) in 2018 - 2019 (grant №18-01-0015) and by the Russian Academic Excellence Project <<5-100>>., I would like to thank Jordan Gans-Morse, Andrei Yakovlev and Andrei Klimenko for their help in collecting the data. I also thank Jesse Campbell, the editor of HSE Working paper series on Public and Social Policy for his helpful comments on early drafts of this paper

H2. perceiving one's job as a calling is associated with higher job satisfaction (H2a), lower turnover intention (H2b) and higher subjective well-being (H2c); 3. H3. perceiving one's job as a calling is linked to basic psychological needs satisfaction; 4. H4. Basic psychological needs satisfaction mediates the relationship between calling and work-related outcomes (job satisfaction (H4a) / turnover intention (H4b) / subjective well-being (H4c)).

attributes.title: Political Speech and Attitudes toward Immigrants

q1.value: Political Speech and Attitudes toward Immigrants

q2.value: Petra Schleiter | Margit Tavits | Dalston Ward

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In this study, we test the potential of pro-immigration political rhetoric to reduce prejudiced attitudes toward immigrants. We are interested in three specific themes that pro-immigrant political rhetoric can emphasize. First, we consider rhetoric that counters negative stereotypes about immigrants by providing factual information about immigrants’ positive contributions to the economy. We label this Countering Stereotypes (CS). Second, we consider rhetoric that calls on honoring and respecting norms of tolerance, equality, and acceptance of diversity. We label this Norms (NM). Finally, we consider rhetoric that highlights the common humanity shared by host communities and immigrants. We label this Common Humanity (CH). We will test the effects of these three types of political rhetoric using a survey experiment.

q16.value: We will estimate the effects of our three treatments (CS, NM, and CH) on our various outcome variables. See attached PAP for details.

q17.value: Treatment effects will be tested through regression analysis of responses to our survey. See attached PAP for details.

q19.value: Approximately 2,000 in two waves of 1,000 each

q24.value: 201807087 at Washington University in St. Louis

attributes.title: Falling Under the Lens of Suspicion: Expressing “Just Enough” Emotion in 911 Calls

q1.value: “Falling Under the Lens of Suspicion: Expressing ‘Just Enough’ Emotion in 911 Calls”  Study 2

q2.value: Jessica Salerno, Samantha Bean, Nicholas Duran

q3.value: Anecdotal evidence suggests that people might fall under suspicion when they violate others’ expectations of appropriate emotion by expressing too much or too little emotion. This project focuses on the earliest point someone might become a suspect in a criminal investigation—when they call 911 to report a violent crime. Within this project, this second study will use 911 calls we created with voice actors. We have a call set of 9 actors (4 men and 5 women) who each express low, moderate, and high emotion within a set call script. This study will include measures of emotion, suspiciousness, and support for police resources and the caller to be investigated as a subject in the crime.

q4.value: We predict an interaction between caller gender and caller emotion. For male callers, we predict a curvilinear pattern, such that people will be more suspicious of low and high emotion relative to moderate emotion. In contrast, for female callers, we expect that low emotion will be significantly more suspicious than both moderate or high emotion (which we do not expect to differ).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We have a 2x3 between subjects design: gender of the caller (male, female) and emotion of the caller (low, moderate, high). Participants will be randomly assigned to listen to one phone call.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon’s Mechanical Turk and will be compensated $1.50 for their time. Participants must be at least 18 years of age.

q13.value: Based on the effect size for the gender x emotion interaction (pη2=.05), we need 244 participants to achieve 90% power to detect the interaction effect. Based on our prediction that a moderator will attenuate the original effect (i.e., we expect the difference between moderate and high emotion that we predict for male callers, to disappear for female callers), we will follow recommendations to multiply the required sample to detect the interaction effect (Giner-Sorolla, Powering your interaction, 2018), which equals 976 participants.

question.value: We will manipulate what level of emotion participants hear in the 911 call (low, moderate, or high), and we will manipulate if this comes from a woman or man expressing this emotion.

Outcome variables for this study will include how suspicious they found the caller, likelihood that the caller was involved in the crime, support for police resources and involvement in investigating the caller. Additionally, we will assess the demographics of participants. 
Open-ended question at the beginning of survey “Please tell us about your first impressions of the caller. Please write a few sentences describing your impression of the person and behaviors that led you to that impression” 

(2)  Eight impressions scales derived from research identifying markers of deception in 911 callers (Harpster, Adams, & Jarvis; 2009) and linguistic deception literature (Duran et al., 2010). Each scale was based on 5-items with 5-point response scales from Not at all to Extremely assessing the caller’s:

Urgency for victim (e.g., “Caller seemed worried about the victim”)
Urgency for self (e.g., “Caller seemed concerned for their own safety”)
Emotionality (e.g., “Caller was hysterical”; α=.92)
Cognitive load (e.g., “Caller seemed to have trouble thinking clearly”; α=.87)
Impression management (e.g., “Caller was actively trying to make a good impression on the dispatcher”; (α=.74)
Information management (e.g., “Caller seemed to be concerned about how much detailed information they should provide”; (α=.58)
Voice characteristics (e.g., “caller’s volume changed a lot”) 
Suspiciousness/violation of expectations (e.g., “I was genuinely surprised about how the caller acted”) 

(3) Moral agency and moral patiency scales adapted from the literature. Both scales were based on 5-items with 6-point response scales from Strongly disagree to Strongly agree. 
Moral patiency (e.g., “The caller seems very vulnerable”)
Moral agency (e.g., “The caller seems like someone who could be capable of doing immoral things”) 

(4) Outcome variables assessing perceptions of suspiciousness, sincerity, and potential role in crime of the caller. Additionally, support for police resources and involvement in investigating the caller.

We will conduct between-subjects ANOVA to test the impact of our manipulations on all continuous outcomes. We will conduct a multiple regression to conduct exploratory analyses regarding which of the five impression scales predict suspiciousness and willingness to spend police resources on investigating them as a suspect.

q22.value:
We will exclude participants who spontaneously indicate that they believe the call was a fake 911 call. This will be assessed in an open-ended question asking for their initial thoughts and comments about the call they heard, before completing other measures for the study. 

Before conducting our main analyses, we will look to see if any of the actors were not believable or were outliers in terms of their emotionality. First, if more than half of participants spontaneously report that they thought the call was fake, we will consider cutting people who heard that actors’ call. 

In addition, if participants rate an actor to be +/- 2SD in terms of emotionality (i.e., making them an outlier actor, e.g., happen to have given a much less emotional performance than all other actors in the “high emotion” category), we will exclude participants who heard that actor’s call.

q24.value: We will conduct exploratory analyses regarding which of the eight impressions scales predict perceived suspiciousness and willingness to spend police resources on investigating them as a suspect. Additionally, we will conduct exploratory analyses with moral agency and patiency as potential mediators of the effect of the gender x emotion expression interaction on suspiciousness.

attributes.title: TNBCdelay
attributes.description: Observation study exploring delay time in diagnosis of TNBC with other subtypes

q1.value: Diagnostic Delay in Triple Negative Breast Cancer

q3.value: Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is defined by lack of expression of estrogen, progesterone and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 receptors (Brenton, Carey, Ahmed, and Caldas, 2005), while hormone receptor-positive breast cancer, on the other hand, is so named because this breast cancer has a significant number of receptors for either estrogen or progesterone. TNBC has been noted to lack the typical suspicious features in mammogram of breast cancer, such as irregular shape, spiculated margins, and suspicious calcifications (Dogan and Turnbull, 2012), leading to incorrect diagnosis of this aggressive breast cancer as benign, which may lead to poor treatment decisions and worse patient outcomes. This study will examine diagnostic delay in triple negative breast cancer, as compared to hormone receptor positive breast cancer.

q4.value:
1-Diagnostic delay is not well described in the literature, so here we quantify the number of patients in each group to experience delay and the median delay time.
2-Misdiagnosis is thought to be associated with aggressiveness of the tumor, but we hypothesise an association between histological subtype and diagnostic delay when restricting to aggressive tumors only.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Breast cancer histological type is not known before diagnosis, therefore it is also not known before delay.

question.value: Observational study comparing 2 histological groups in terms of diagnostic delay (primary interest) and characteristics of participants and tumors.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: This study will analyse data collected in routine practice at the Breast Centre Zurich between January 2005 and December 2018. The data will be exported by CE and colleagues and KAR is given access specifically for analysis. KAR is responsible for analysis of the data. Analysis takes place after the protocol/statistical analysis plan is agreed upon.

question.value: The data was collected as part of routine care at the Breast Centre Zurich from January 2015 through December 2018. The export was based on all patients diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer or aggressive (intermediate or poorly differentiated grading level 2 or 3) hormone receptor positive breast cancer patients. The number of nonaggressive (well differentiated, level 1) triple negative breast cancers is expected to be low and they will be excluded from the study so that both groups only contain aggressive tumors. Patients for which histopathological results informed BIRADS rating/occured before rating will also be excluded.

q13.value: The sample size is based on the number of observations collected in routine care during the time period from January 2015 to December 2018. The total sample size in the dataset prior to applying the inclusion/exclusion criteria is 782 patients.

q14.value: The sample size is constrained by the number of patients seen at Breast Centre Zurich between January 2015 and December 2018 that are diagnosed with wither triple negative or hormone receptor positive breast cancer.

question.value:
The primary outcome is diagnostic delay. Patients experiencing a diagnostic delay are those with tumors classified as benign using the American College of Radiology’s Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS, categories 1-3 as opposed to categories 4 or higher) at first consultation for a new breast cancer, but then later identified as having a malignant breast cancer. Diagnostic delay will be analysed in the  following forms:
1- a binary variable for whether or not a patient experiences a diagnostic delay
2- the delay time (time between incorrect diagnosis and correct diagnosis) in days

The primary predictor of interest is the histological breast cancer type (triple negative breast cancer versus hormone receptor positive breast cancer), which is a binary variable.

Covariates: Patient characteristics include age (continuous), menopause status (binary), family history of breast cancer (binary), breast density (classification according to American College of Radiology, categorical), and reason for consultation (categorical). Tumor characteristics include multifocal nature (binary), BIRADS category (categorical), size (continuous), grading (after exclusion of highly differentiated tumors, a binary variable with the levels intermediate or poorly differentiated), and accompanying suspicious lymph nodes (binary).

The first outcome is the proportion of patients experiencing a diagnostic delay. These proportions will be reported with two-sided 95% confidence intervals.

To compare these proportions, an odds ratio will be used to compare these proportions, so that the unadjusted measure may be compared to an adjusted measure later in analysis.

Diagnostic delay time will be summarized by the median (IQR) across groups and analysed using the Wicoxon Mann Whitney test.

Multivariable analysis will use a firth logistic model to compare the proportion of patients experiencing diagnostic delay across the two groups while adjusting for confounders. This model yields the adjusted odds ratio and a two-sided 95% confidence interval. This adjusted measure is considered our primary outcome. The number of "events" is assumed to be low, so a propensity score (based on logistic regression) will be used to adjust for several covariates using a single continuous variable.

Tables will be used to describe the distribution of patient characteristics (age, menopause status, family history of breast cancer, breast density, and reason for consultation), tumor characteristics (multifocal, BIRADS, size, grading, suspicious lymph nodes), and treatment type (chemotherapy, radiotherapy, endocrine therapy). Categorical variables will be summarized by number (proportion). Age will be summarized with mean (sd) and delay time and tumor size by median (IQR).

q20.value: The BIRADS score will be transformed from the multi-categorical classification of the American College of Radiology to a binary variable for whether the tumor was classified as probably/benign or probably/malignant.

q21.value: The standard p-value<0.05 criteria will be used for interpretation of significance. P-values reported in the tables will be considered exploratory, not inferential.

q22.value: Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: Complete case analysis will be performed, unless substantial data is missing (>10%). If substantial data is missing, missingness patterns will be explored and multiple imputation methods will be used.

q3.value:
Examines whether an addressee's expectations about how a speaker will refer to a particular object are influenced by how the speaker previously referred to objects.

When participants are entrained to identify an item using a more specific label, will they look more at other items when the shorter label is used for the same item (lexical entrainment effect)?
When participants have an established label for an item, will they look more at other items when the same label is used for a different item (lexical differentiation effect)?

q4.value:
We predicted that participants would expect to hear the same reference phrase to refer to the object, even when the reference is over-informative (lexical entrainment effect).
We may find that participants would be distracted by other items when using a used label for a new item (lexical differentiation effect).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: 2-way repeated measures ANOVAs (entrainment/differentiation/baseline and short/long label).  Run separately for each dependent variable.

q9.value: 252 trials will be presented in the same order, with 4 versions counterbalanced across participants. 60 fillers trials will be presented within the 252 trials.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: No researchers have accessed any data files prior to this registration.

question.value: Participants will be recruited on Carleton campus, filtering for native english speakers. Participants will be compensated $11 for approximately 30-60 minutes of their time. Participants will need to be native English speakers and be above 18-years-old. The data will be collected January through March 2020.  We may be unable to use some participants’ data if the eyetracker produces unusable data (e.g. all fixations outside the target item regions).

q14.value: Actual number of participants may vary slightly due to participants failing to complete the study or additional participants engaging with the study.

q15.value: We will stop collecting data once we have usable data from 32 participants.

question.value:
Preliminary trial type: entrainment vs. differentiation.  Also compare with the baseline trial (the first differentiation trial).
Test trial label: long vs. short name of the target item.

Reaction time (to mouse click)
Time to first fixation of target item (fixation defined as >200 ms)
Proportion of looks to target

2-way repeated measures ANOVAs.  Run separately for each dependent variable.
T-tests as post-hoc follow-ups for main effects.
Length of first fixation on the target item.

q21.value: We will use a general alpha of .05 for all tests.  All t-tests will be conducted two-tailed.

q22.value:
Participants will be excluded if they fail to complete more than 95% of the trials.
In case the eye tracker does not provide valid data points (for more than 70% of trials) for certain participants, their data would be excluded as well.

q23.value:
Participants with a substantial number of missing responses (>5%) will be excluded from data analysis.
Conditions with missing data will be averaged without the missing items.

q24.value:
Linear mixed effects models - 2 fixed effects (entrainment vs. differentiation vs. baseline, short vs. long label), 2 random effects (participant, stimulus item).  Run separately for each dependent variable.
More eye tracking analysis, e.g. time to first fixation.

registration_responses.q3:
Examines whether an addressee's expectations about how a speaker will refer to a particular object are influenced by how the speaker previously referred to objects.

When participants are entrained to identify an item using a more specific label, will they look more at other items when the shorter label is used for the same item (lexical entrainment effect)?
When participants have an established label for an item, will they look more at other items when the same label is used for a different item (lexical differentiation effect)?
registration_responses.q4:
We predicted that participants would expect to hear the same reference phrase to refer to the object, even when the reference is over-informative (lexical entrainment effect).
We may find that participants would be distracted by other items when using a used label for a new item (lexical differentiation effect).
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: 252 trials will be presented in the same order, with 4 versions counterbalanced across participants. 60 fillers trials will be presented within the 252 trials.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to any human observation of the data
registration_responses.q11: No researchers have accessed any data files prior to this registration.
registration_responses.q14: Actual number of participants may vary slightly due to participants failing to complete the study or additional participants engaging with the study.
registration_responses.q15: We will stop collecting data once we have usable data from 32 participants.
registration_responses.q21: We will use a general alpha of .05 for all tests.  All t-tests will be conducted two-tailed.
registration_responses.q22:
Participants will be excluded if they fail to complete more than 95% of the trials.
In case the eye tracker does not provide valid data points (for more than 70% of trials) for certain participants, their data would be excluded as well.
registration_responses.q23:
Participants with a substantial number of missing responses (>5%) will be excluded from data analysis.
Conditions with missing data will be averaged without the missing items.
registration_responses.q24:
Linear mixed effects models - 2 fixed effects (entrainment vs. differentiation vs. baseline, short vs. long label), 2 random effects (participant, stimulus item).  Run separately for each dependent variable.
More eye tracking analysis, e.g. time to first fixation.
registration_responses.q8.question: 2-way repeated measures ANOVAs (entrainment/differentiation/baseline and short/long label).  Run separately for each dependent variable.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited on Carleton campus, filtering for native english speakers. Participants will be compensated $11 for approximately 30-60 minutes of their time. Participants will need to be native English speakers and be above 18-years-old. The data will be collected January through March 2020.  We may be unable to use some participants’ data if the eyetracker produces unusable data (e.g. all fixations outside the target item regions).
registration_responses.q16.question:
Preliminary trial type: entrainment vs. differentiation.  Also compare with the baseline trial (the first differentiation trial).
Test trial label: long vs. short name of the target item.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Reaction time (to mouse click)
Time to first fixation of target item (fixation defined as >200 ms)
Proportion of looks to target
registration_responses.q19.question:
2-way repeated measures ANOVAs.  Run separately for each dependent variable.
T-tests as post-hoc follow-ups for main effects.
Length of first fixation on the target item.

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun

attributes.title: Feasiblity study: Registered Reports funding models
attributes.description: The overarching aim of our study is to determine the feasibility of conducting an RCT to answer the question: ‘how do RR partnerships, in which funders and journals collaborate to offer authors RRs, affect the efficiency and quality of scientific funding, research and publishing?’.

q1.value: Katie Drax, Jacqueline Thompson, Chris Chambers, Marcus Munafo, Robbie Clark

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will conduct a thematic analysis of semi-structured interviews about participants’ experiences and opinions of partnerships. We will propose a potential design of a RCT to investigate the impacts of partnerships. The interviews will inform these methods, but we may also collect and analyse data from journals and funders.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: We have already conducted four semi-structured interviews. We have made no major changes to the protocol since our first interview.

question.value:
To understand the full range of experiences in each of the funder-journal partnerships we would need to recruit at least one person from each model for each of the four stakeholder groups: (1) authors of partnership submissions, (2) personnel at partner funders, (3) editors at partner journals, and (4) reviewers of partnership submissions.  

# Inclusion criteria 

Aged 18 years or above 

Have experience coordinating a funder-journal RR partnership as a journal editor or funding body representative and/or experience authoring or reviewing submissions to a funder-journal RR partnership. 

# Recruitment strategy 

We will use combination of convenience and snowball sampling for recruitment (Robinson, 2014). We will first identify prospective participants using publicly available information and from our existing relationships with personnel from the journals and funders involved in partnerships. We will also ask editor and funder participants to recommend others who may qualify for participation.

q12.value:
Sample size determination 

 We aim to use quota sampling (Robinson, 2014) to sample at least one person from each partnership for each of the four stakeholder groups. This would achieve the equal distribution across the cells shown in Table 1 (see Table 1 in RRFM_protocol_v1.0.pdf) and give N = 24 (6 partnerships * 4 stakeholder categories).

q13.value:
We anticipate that due to constraints of participant availability, time and costs, it is likely we will not be able to cover all cells in Table 1  (see Table 1 in RRFM_protocol_v1.0.pdf) .

The quotas will change if more partnerships emerge.

question.value: NA - We may also collect and analyse data from journals and funders about the efficiency of the partnership process. The interviews will inform the variables collected.

q22.value: Interviews analysed using thematic analysis. The average, variation and relationships of any quantitative data collected from journals or funders will be explored.

We will propose a potential design of a RCT to investigate the impacts of partnerships. The interviews will inform these methods, but we may also collect and analyse data from journals and funders.

# Inclusion criteria 

Aged 18 years or above 

Have experience coordinating a funder-journal RR partnership as a journal editor or funding body representative and/or experience authoring or reviewing submissions to a funder-journal RR partnership. 

# Recruitment strategy 

We will use combination of convenience and snowball sampling for recruitment (Robinson, 2014). attributes.title: Spatial frequencies - Decoding emotion expressions
attributes.description: Short experiment designed to investigate how alterations to the available information in a perceiver's visual field (via spatial frequency filtering) impacts their ability to decode emotion expressions. Study 1a includes thirty identities displaying three emotions matched on valence (fear, anger, disgust) while Study 1b includes the same thirty identities displaying three emotions matched on arousal (open-mouthed joy, fear, surprise). In both studies, participants see each identity displaying each emotion, with each individual's face appearing in one of three spatial frequency categories (intact spatial frequency, high spatial frequency, low spatial frequency). In study 1a, participants are asked to provide measurements of emotional negativity, arousal level, a 3AFC of which emotion is displayed and their confidence in their judgments. In study 1b, participants provide measurements of emotional valence, arousal intensity, a 3AFC of which emotion is displayed, and their confidence in their judgments. Predictions and analysis plans are discussed.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: On emotion detection and spatial frequency filtering

other.value: Confidence ratings for each individual emotion at the differing spatial frequency levels will be explored. There are no a priori hypotheses.

sample.value:
A power analysis conducted in PANGEA (Westfall, 2016) with 3 replicates per participant indicated that data from 150 participants would afford us 80.8% power to detect a minimum effect of d = .20. This power analysis was conducted specifying the most stringent contrasts, those being the average of two conditions contrasted against one condition in both the spatial frequency and emotion factors (i.e., a -1, -1, 2 contrast for both factors) for all linear mixed effects models. 

A second power analysis conducted for the ANOVAs indicated that 150 participants affords us 82.7% power to detect a minimum effect of d = .22. These analyses again specified the most stringent contrasts (-1, -1, 2) for the frequencies factor. Each model will be conducted on each emotion in isolation for the signal detection analyses.

analyses.value:
We will regress the each of the emotion (fear, anger, disgust) ratings (valence, arousal, category, confidence) on spatial frequency (3 levels: broad, high, low), counterbalancing order (3 sets), and their interaction in a multilevel model that contains random intercepts for participants and stimuli to ensure that the counterbalancing order did not produce any effects or interact with the frequencies in any way. Following this, analyses will be collapsed across counterbalancing blocks and only focus on spatial frequency condition and emotion type. 

The first test will be an analysis of variance (ANOVA) examining the effect of frequency condition on emotion identification, valence, arousal, and confidence with follow-up tests using Tukey's method to compare differences between broad and high frequencies, broad and low frequencies, and high and low frequencies for each DV.

Next, emotion (valence, arousal) and confidence ratings will each be entered into cross-classified MLMs with random intercepts for participants and stimuli. We will specify contrasts for broad and high frequency faces versus low frequency faces, broad frequency faces versus high frequency faces, broad frequency faces versus low frequency faces, and high frequency faces versus low frequency faces. We will also specify contrasts for fear and disgust vs. anger, fear and anger vs. disgust, and anger and disgust vs. fear. We will report this model if model fit indices and model convergence indicate a good fit.

For the emotion category analysis, we will calculate participants’ d’ and β scores using the framework of signal detection. These scores will be entered into a one-way repeated-measures ANOVA, analyzing mean differences in sensitivity and bias between each of the three frequency conditions. Post-hoc tests will examine these differences using Tukey's method. Secondary analyses will be conducted using linear mixed models that specify a random slope for frequency condition for each participant, specifying the four contrasts identified above.

outliers.value: Participants displaying non-variance in responses will be excluded from analyses. Additionally, participants who did not follow directions will be excluded. Missing values will be excluded on a trial-by-trial basis to preserve as much of our original sample as possible.

dependent.value:
There are 4 target dependent variables: emotion negativity (i.e., how negative), arousal, emotion expression category, and confidence of judgment. 

Following stimulus presentation (1000ms), participants will rate arousal from extremely low arousal to extremely high arousal, negativity from not at all to extremely, then will choose the emotion category the believe the face to be expressing from the ones listed (fear, anger, or disgust), and will lastly give a confidence rating of their choice on a scale of not at all to extremely (all scales are 1 - 7).

conditions.value:
This study will be a 3 by 3 fully within-subjects design, counterbalanced across participants. 

The first within-subjects condition involves three conditions: low spatial frequency emotion expression faces, high spatial frequency emotion expression faces, and broad spatial frequency emotion expression faces. The second within-subjects condition involves three emotions: fear, anger, and disgust. 

Participants will see faces in all three conditions, with spatially filtered faces being counterbalanced between participants (i.e., participants will see each face and emotion expression in only one of the three filtering conditions).

hypothesis.value:
Question: 

A prior pilot study yielded evidence that disrupting a person's ability to process faces by manipulating spatial frequency content affects their ability to accurately categorize emotion expressions. This was particularly true when individuals were tasked with differentiating between emotions that were similar either in arousal or valence. 

This study will extend that work to better understand how bottom-up disruptions to face processing hinder abilities to accurately differentiate between emotion categorization for emotions matched on valence. We will investigate ratings of emotion negativity, arousal, confidence, and the target emotion categorization. We have also indicated places where we have competing predictions based on pilot data results and the extant literature. 

Hypotheses: 

General Spatial Frequency: 

H1a: We predict that emotion categorization will be most accurate for non-filtered images (i.e., intact spatial frequency images or ISF).
H1b: We predict that emotion categorization will be least accurate for low spatial frequency (LSF) images (i.e., those with only low spatial frequencies present).
H1c: We predict that emotion categorization will be moderately accurate (between high and non-filtered) for high spatial frequency (HSF) images (i.e., those with only high spatial frequencies present).

Competing Predictions:

H2a: We predict that participants' ratings (i.e., emotional negativity and arousal) for LSF images will be similar to those of non-filtered image, but different from those of HSF images. 
H2b: We predict that participants' ratings (i.e., emotional negativity and arousal) for HSF images will be similar to those of non-filtered image, but different from those of LSF images. 

Emotion Specific:

H3a: We predict that anger will be rated as most emotionally negative and arousing compared to disgust and fear because anger is a direct threat (i.e., displaying threat to the observer). We predict this to be true for the ISF and HSF images. 
H3b: We predict that anger and disgust will not evidence differences for emotional negativity and arousal (vs. fear) for LSF. 
H3c: We predict that fear will be rated more emotionally negative and arousing than disgust (but less than anger) for LSF images. We predict that disgust will be more negative for ISF images. 

We have no specific predictions for fear for HSF images.

registration_responses.hypothesis:
Question: 

A prior pilot study yielded evidence that disrupting a person's ability to process faces by manipulating spatial frequency content affects their ability to accurately categorize emotion expressions. This was particularly true when individuals were tasked with differentiating between emotions that were similar either in arousal or valence. 

This study will extend that work to better understand how bottom-up disruptions to face processing hinder abilities to accurately differentiate between emotion categorization for emotions matched on valence. We will investigate ratings of emotion negativity, arousal, confidence, and the target emotion categorization. We have also indicated places where we have competing predictions based on pilot data results and the extant literature. 

Hypotheses: 

General Spatial Frequency: 

H1a: We predict that emotion categorization will be most accurate for non-filtered images (i.e., intact spatial frequency images or ISF).
H1b: We predict that emotion categorization will be least accurate for low spatial frequency (LSF) images (i.e., those with only low spatial frequencies present).
H1c: We predict that emotion categorization will be moderately accurate (between high and non-filtered) for high spatial frequency (HSF) images (i.e., those with only high spatial frequencies present).

Competing Predictions:

H2a: We predict that participants' ratings (i.e., emotional negativity and arousal) for LSF images will be similar to those of non-filtered image, but different from those of HSF images. 
H2b: We predict that participants' ratings (i.e., emotional negativity and arousal) for HSF images will be similar to those of non-filtered image, but different from those of LSF images. 

Emotion Specific:

H3a: We predict that anger will be rated as most emotionally negative and arousing compared to disgust and fear because anger is a direct threat (i.e., displaying threat to the observer). We predict this to be true for the ISF and HSF images. 
H3b: We predict that anger and disgust will not evidence differences for emotional negativity and arousal (vs. fear) for LSF. 
H3c: We predict that fear will be rated more emotionally negative and arousing than disgust (but less than anger) for LSF images. We predict that disgust will be more negative for ISF images. 

We have no specific predictions for fear for HSF images.

attributes.title: Spatial frequencies - Decoding emotion expressions
attributes.description: Short experiment designed to investigate how alterations to the available information in a perceiver's visual field (via spatial frequency filtering) impacts their ability to decode emotion expressions. Study 1a includes thirty identities displaying three emotions matched on valence (fear, anger, disgust) while Study 1b includes the same thirty identities displaying three emotions matched on arousal (open-mouthed joy, fear, surprise). In both studies, participants see each identity displaying each emotion, with each individual's face appearing in one of three spatial frequency categories (intact spatial frequency, high spatial frequency, low spatial frequency). In study 1a, participants are asked to provide measurements of emotional negativity, arousal level, a 3AFC of which emotion is displayed and their confidence in their judgments. In study 1b, participants provide measurements of emotional valence, arousal intensity, a 3AFC of which emotion is displayed, and their confidence in their judgments. Predictions and analysis plans are discussed.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: On emotion detection and spatial frequency filtering: Matched arousal emotions

other.value: Confidence ratings for each individual emotion at the differing spatial frequency levels will be explored. There are no a priori hypotheses.

sample.value:
A power analysis conducted in PANGEA (Westfall, 2016) with 3 replicates per participant indicated that data from 150 participants would afford us 80.8% power to detect a minimum effect of d = .20. This power analysis was conducted specifying the most stringent contrasts, those being the average of two conditions contrasted against one condition in both the spatial frequency and emotion factors (i.e., a -1, -1, 2 contrast for both factors) for all linear mixed effects models. 

A second power analysis conducted for the ANOVAs indicated that 150 participants affords us 82.7% power to detect a minimum effect of d = .22. These analyses again specified the most stringent contrasts (-1, -1, 2) for the frequencies factor. Each model will be conducted on each emotion in isolation for the signal detection analyses.

analyses.value:
We will regress each of the emotion (joy, surprise, fear) ratings (valence, arousal, category, confidence) on spatial frequency (3 levels: broad, high, low), counterbalancing order (3 sets), and their interaction in a multilevel model that contains random intercepts for participants and stimuli to ensure that the counterbalancing order did not produce any effects or interact with the frequencies in any way. Following this, analyses will be collapsed across counterbalancing blocks and only focus on spatial frequency condition and emotion type. 

The first test will be an analysis of variance (ANOVA) examining the effect of frequency condition on emotion identification, valence, arousal, and confidence with follow-up tests using Tukey's method to compare differences between broad and high frequencies, broad and low frequencies, and high and low frequencies for each DV.

Next, emotion (valence, arousal) and confidence ratings will each be entered into cross-classified MLMs with random intercepts for participants and stimuli. We will specify contrasts for broad and high frequency faces versus low frequency faces, broad frequency faces versus high frequency faces, broad frequency faces versus low frequency faces, and high frequency faces versus low frequency faces. We will also specify contrasts for joy and surprise vs fear, joy vs surprise, surprise and fear vs joy, and surprise vs fear. We will report this model if model fit indices and model convergence indicate a good fit.

For the emotion category analysis, we will calculate participants’ d’ and β scores using the framework of signal detection. These scores will be entered into a one-way repeated-measures ANOVA, analyzing mean differences in sensitivity and bias between each of the three frequency conditions. Post-hoc tests will examine these differences using Tukey's method. Secondary analyses will be conducted using linear mixed models that specify a random slope for frequency condition for each participant, specifying the four contrasts identified above.

outliers.value: Participants displaying non-variance in responses will be excluded from analyses. Additionally, participants who did not follow directions will be excluded. Missing values will be excluded on a trial-by-trial basis to preserve as much of our original sample as possible.

dependent.value:
There are 4 target dependent variables: emotion valence, arousal intensity, emotion expression category, and confidence of judgment. 

Following stimulus presentation (1000ms), participants will rate arousal intensity from extremely low arousal to extremely high arousal, emotional valence from extremely negative to extremely positive, then will choose the emotion category the believe the face to be expressing from the ones listed (joy, surprise, fear), and will lastly give a confidence rating of their choice on a scale of not at all to extremely (all scales are 1 - 7).

conditions.value:
This study will be a 3 by 3 fully within-subjects design, counterbalanced across participants. 

The first within-subjects condition involves three conditions: low spatial frequency emotion expression faces, high spatial frequency emotion expression faces, and broad spatial frequency emotion expression faces. The second within-subjects condition involves three emotions: joy, surprise, and fear. 

Participants will see faces in all three conditions, with spatially filtered faces being counterbalanced between participants (i.e., participants will see each face and emotion expression in only one of the three filtering conditions).

hypothesis.value:
Question: 

A prior pilot study yielded evidence that disrupting a person's ability to process faces by manipulating spatial frequency content affects their ability to accurately categorize emotion expressions. This was particularly true when individuals were tasked with differentiating between emotions that were similar either in arousal or valence. 

This study will extend that work to better understand how bottom-up disruptions to face processing hinder abilities to accurately differentiate between emotion categorization for emotions matched on arousal. We will investigate ratings of emotion valence, arousal intensity, confidence, and the target emotion categorization. We have also indicated places where we have competing predictions based on pilot data results and the extant literature. 

Hypotheses: 

General Spatial Frequency: 

H1a: We predict that emotion categorization will be most accurate for non-filtered images (i.e., intact spatial frequency images or ISF).
H1b: We predict that emotion categorization will be least accurate for low spatial frequency (LSF) images (i.e., those with only low spatial frequencies present).
H1c: We predict that emotion categorization will be moderately accurate (between high and non-filtered) for high spatial frequency (HSF) images (i.e., those with only high spatial frequencies present).

Competing Predictions:

H2a: We predict that participants' ratings (i.e., emotional valence and arousal intensity) for LSF images will be similar to those of non-filtered image, but different from those of HSF images. 
H2b: We predict that participants' ratings (i.e., emotional valence and arousal intensity) for HSF images will be similar to those of non-filtered image, but different from those of LSF images. 

Emotion Specific:

H3a: We predict that joy will be rated as most emotionally positive, followed by surprise and then fear, which should be rated as the most emotionally negative. We predict this to be true for the ISF and HSF images. 
H3b: We predict that fear and surprise will not evidence any differences in arousal intensity for LSF faces, but will for ISF faces (with fear being more intense than surprise).

The first within-subjects condition involves three conditions: low spatial frequency emotion expression faces, high spatial frequency emotion expression faces, and broad spatial frequency emotion expression faces. The second within-subjects condition involves three emotions: joy, surprise, and fear. 

Participants will see faces in all three conditions, with spatially filtered faces being counterbalanced between participants (i.e., participants will see each face and emotion expression in only one of the three filtering conditions).
registration_responses.hypothesis:
Question: 

A prior pilot study yielded evidence that disrupting a person's ability to process faces by manipulating spatial frequency content affects their ability to accurately categorize emotion expressions. This was particularly true when individuals were tasked with differentiating between emotions that were similar either in arousal or valence. 

This study will extend that work to better understand how bottom-up disruptions to face processing hinder abilities to accurately differentiate between emotion categorization for emotions matched on arousal. We will investigate ratings of emotion valence, arousal intensity, confidence, and the target emotion categorization. We have also indicated places where we have competing predictions based on pilot data results and the extant literature. 

Hypotheses: 

General Spatial Frequency: 

H1a: We predict that emotion categorization will be most accurate for non-filtered images (i.e., intact spatial frequency images or ISF).
H1b: We predict that emotion categorization will be least accurate for low spatial frequency (LSF) images (i.e., those with only low spatial frequencies present).
H1c: We predict that emotion categorization will be moderately accurate (between high and non-filtered) for high spatial frequency (HSF) images (i.e., those with only high spatial frequencies present).

Competing Predictions:

H2a: We predict that participants' ratings (i.e., emotional valence and arousal intensity) for LSF images will be similar to those of non-filtered image, but different from those of HSF images. 
H2b: We predict that participants' ratings (i.e., emotional valence and arousal intensity) for HSF images will be similar to those of non-filtered image, but different from those of LSF images. 

Emotion Specific:

H3a: We predict that joy will be rated as most emotionally positive, followed by surprise and then fear, which should be rated as the most emotionally negative. We predict this to be true for the ISF and HSF images. 
H3b: We predict that fear and surprise will not evidence any differences in arousal intensity for LSF faces, but will for ISF faces (with fear being more intense than surprise).
